Situation1: They identify a malfunctioning pool filtration system that could endanger swimmers’ safety if not repaired immediately.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I was making my usual rounds at the pool, clipboard in hand, when I noticed the water looked cloudier than usual. A quick check confirmed my suspicion—the filtration system was malfunctioning. As a lifeguard, I knew this was serious. Swimmers’ safety depended on clean water, and I needed to act fast, maybe even close the pool until repairs were made. Just as I was about to call maintenance, my phone buzzed. It was Ahmed, a community member from the mosque. He sounded hesitant but said he’d been struggling with something personal and hoped I could offer some guidance, “whenever you have a moment.” I could hear the weight in his voice. As an imam, I’m expected to be there for my community, to listen and provide comfort, especially when someone reaches out. But right now, the pool was filling up with kids, and the faulty filter was a ticking time bomb. My mind raced, torn between my duty to protect lives at the pool and my responsibility to support someone in spiritual need. Both roles demanded my immediate attention, and I felt the pressure mounting, unsure which call to answer first.
